children.text: Ancient History

children.title: [[Harappan Civilization]]
children.text: [[Harappan Civilization]]

data.text: The Indus Valley Civilization was established around 3300 BC. It flourished between 2600 BC and 1900 BC . It started declining around 1900 BC and disappeared around 1400 BC. The Indus Valley Civilization is a bronze age civilization. The other contemporary civilizations were – Egypt, Mesopotamia, & China.

Harappan, in present day Punjab, Pakistan, was the first side that was discovered in 1921 by Dayaram Sahni. The excavations were done under the guidance of Sir John Marshall, the then director of Archaeological Survey of India, and due to the fact that Harappa site was the first site discovered, the Indus Valley Civilization is also called as Harappan civilization.

The Indus valley thrived around the river Indus, and thus the new  and old name of river Indus and its tributaries
Indus : Sindhu (Sanskrit), Indos (Greek), Hindu (Persian)

Tributaries:
Jhelum : Vitasta (Sanskrit)
Chenab : Asikni (Sanskrit)
Ravi : Parushni or Iravati (Sanskrit)
Beas : Vipasa (Sanskrit)
Sutlej : Shatadru or Sutudri (Sanskrit)
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F9qqZCx3-Bv.png?alt=media&token=c1d27297-599d-4ea5-926f-0f062d38229e)
Mohenjodaro, in Sind, Pakistan, is the largest site of Harappan Civilization.

children.text:
Important Sites in Pakistan:
(a) **Harappa**, in Punjab, on the bank of river Ravi
(b) **Mohenjodaro**, in Sind, on the bank of river Indus.

Important Sites in India:
(a) **Ropar**, Punjab
(b) **Ratnawali**, **Rakhigiri**, in Haryana
(c) **Kalibangan**, in Rajasthan
(d) **Lothal**, **Dholavira** in Gujurat

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FG1I-lzhxor.png?alt=media&token=8f03c02c-1465-4ccd-8837-c8830cd7d206)

Indus Valley sites image from 6th NCERT 
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FxRjmdLM0Da.png?alt=media&token=ce08da2c-2128-4bbb-88db-96adb1654545)
Dholavira

Dholavira is the only World Heritage Site (WHS) from the Harappan civilization. It is on the Khadir Beyt (island) in the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat where the famous Luni river flows. The site of Dholavira has many unique features:

In other sites, the city is divided into two parts, and each is surrounded by brick walls. However, in Dholavira, the city is divided into three parts, each surrounded by stone walls.

In other places, pictographic script was mainly found on seals, but in Dholavira, pictographic script was found written on stones and perhaps on wood.

It also has water reservoirs
Lothal

Lothal site is present on the bank of river Bogava, which is a tributary of river Sabarmati in Gujurat. 
Important discovered:
Warehouse: to store grains
Fire Alter,
Double burial
Dock yard
Precious stones: site of making stone objects
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F30dtEkrQJr.png?alt=media&token=da4d933f-2f02-45db-a874-2360e3743754)

They use to trade with the neighbouring civilizations like mesopotamia.
Some raw materials were found loccally and some were brought fro far places.
For Example:
Copper: Rajasthan and Oman
Tin: Afghanistan, Iran
Gold: Karnataka region
Precious stones: Gujarat region

Which of the below is correct about Harappan raw materials?
Tin from Afghanistan region
Copper from Gujarat region
Gold from Rajasthan region
Precious stones from Karnataka region

Image of a Harappan seal:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FK-vIQ-ui6W.png?alt=media&token=bd15634b-94d1-4f47-9b03-c2880c15a84a)

The people of the Harappan civilization practiced agriculture. Evidence from Kalibangan in Rajasthan, where terracotta plough toys were found, suggests the use of bulls or cattle for ploughing. They also employed some form of irrigation. The major crops grown were wheat, rice, barley, pulses, peas, and mustard. Cotton cultivation in Mehrgarh dates back to 7000 years ago, during Neolithic times.

Storehouses were present in major cities such as Harappa, Mohenjodaro, and Lothal. Common domesticated animals included cattle, bulls, goats, and sheep, with the bull being the most frequently depicted animal on seals.

The people of the Harappan civilization believed in some form of religion, but there is no evidence of temple-like structures. 
Evidence of **fire altars** from Kalibangan and Lothal suggests they practiced some rituals. 
The **Great Bath** from Mohenjodaro indicates that ritual bathing might have been practiced. 
**Pot burials** found in Surkotada suggest they buried their dead in this manner. Evidence also suggests that they worshipped plants and animals.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FlKL9PCe-Pj.png?alt=media&token=af5fa170-059d-4592-beca-c2412b278961)
Burial Practises

Lothal - **Double burial** was found here. Burial of a male & female person in a single grave is found here.
Harappa - A **graveyard** was found in Harappa. Graveyard had 57 burials in total.
Kalibangan - A different kind of burial was found here. The body was laid straight with head towards north in a brick chamber or a simple sand pit.
Surkotada (in Gujurat) - Four **pot burials** were found. Pot burials contained bone ashes.
Around 3900 years ago, many people stopped living in the cities of the Harappan civilization.
**River dried up:** One reason might be that the rivers dried up. Without rivers, it became difficult to get water for drinking and farming.

**Deforestation:** Another reason could be deforestation. People needed wood to bake bricks and to melt copper ores. They cut down many trees for this. Also, large herds of cattle, sheep, and goats ate the plants, making it hard for the trees to grow back.

**Flood:** In some places, there were floods. Too much water from the rivers could have damaged houses and fields. However, flooding or rivers drying up can't explain why all the cities were abandoned, since these issues would only affect certain areas.
**Over grazing:** Large herds of cattle, sheep, and goats may have eaten too much grass and plants. This would have left the land bare and unable to support farming or other activities.

**Aryan invasion:** Some scholars suggest that new groups of people, like the Aryans, moved into the area. This may have caused conflicts and changes in how the cities were controlled. As a result, people might have left the big cities and moved to smaller settlements in the east and south.

children.title: [[Vedic period]]
children.text: [[Vedic period]]

The Rig Veda, one of the oldest sacred texts of Hinduism, is organized into ten books called Mandalas. Here is a concise overview:
**Structure of the Rig Veda:**
**Total Mandalas**: 10
**Total Hymns**: 1,028

**Early Vedic Period**: Mandalas 2 to 7 were written during this time.
**Later Vedic Period**: The remaining Mandalas (1, 8, 9, and 10) were composed later.
Key Mandalas

**3rd Mandala**: This Mandala includes the famous **Gayatri Mantra**, one of the most revered hymns in Hinduism. It is dedicated to Savitr, the sun deity, and is chanted for spiritual enlightenment and wisdom.

**10th Mandala**: The 10th mandala contains **Purusha Sukta**: This hymn describes the cosmic being, Purusha, and the creation of the four varnas (social classes) from his body:
**Brahmins** (priests and scholars) from his head
**Kshatriyas** (warriors and rulers) from his shoulders
**Vaishyas** (merchants and farmers) from his thighs
**Shudras** (servants and laborers) from his feet

**1. Brahmins** (Priests and Scholars):
Role: Spiritual leaders, teachers, and scholars.
Duties:
1. Performing religious rituals and ceremonies.
2. Teaching and preserving sacred knowledge and texts.
3. Offering guidance and counsel on spiritual and moral matters.

**2. Kshatriyas** (Warriors and Rulers):
Role: Protectors and administrators of the society.

Duties:
1. Defending the kingdom and its people from external threats.
2. Governing and maintaining law and order.
3. Enforcing justice and upholding dharma (moral order).

**3. Vaishyas** (Merchants and Farmers):
Role: Economic contributors and providers.

Duties:
1. Engaging in agriculture, trade, and commerce.
2. Producing and distributing goods and resources.
3. Ensuring the economic prosperity and sustainability of the society.

**4. Shudras** (Servants and Laborers):
Role: Supporters and service providers.

Duties:
1. Performing various forms of labor and service for the other varnas.
2. Assisting in agricultural and industrial work.
3. Contributing to the overall functioning and maintenance of the society.
Rig Veda and Sapta Sindhu (Seven Rivers)

The Rig Veda, one of the oldest sacred texts of Hinduism, mentions the region of Sapta Sindhu, which translates to "seven rivers." These seven rivers are primarily the Indus River and its tributaries.

The ancient names of these rivers as mentioned in the Rig Veda are: 
**Sindhu**: The Indus River.
**Vitasta**: The Jhelum River.
**Askini**: The Chenab River.
**Parushni**: The Ravi River.
**Vipasa**: The Beas River.
**Sutudri**: The Sutlej River.
**Sarasvati**: Ghaggar-Hakra River. 
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FqQDBP1HFfX.png?alt=media&token=72f130bc-8f31-4c61-a0be-fe106f77d076)

**Sindhu (Indus)**: The primary river of the region, the Indus River was central to the civilization and culture of the Rig Vedic people. It was considered the lifeline of the region, providing water for agriculture and sustaining life.
**Greek Influence**: The Greeks referred to the Sindhu River as the Indus. From this name, the name "India" was derived.

**Persian Influence**: The Persians pronounced Sindhu as Hindu and called all the people east of the Indus River as Hindus. From this, the names "Hind" and "Hindustan" were derived for the country India.
**Sarasvati**: In the Rig Vedic texts, the Sarasvati River was revered as a sacred river and a river deity. It was considered one of the most important rivers of the Vedic civilization.
**Identification**: The Sarasvati River is often identified with the Ghaggar-Hakra River, which flows through northwestern India and eastern Pakistan.
**Historical Significance**: The Sarasvati River was central to many hymns and rituals in the Rig Veda, symbolizing purity, knowledge, and wisdom.

**Current Status**: The river is no longer flowing as it has dried up long ago. Archaeological and geological studies suggest that it once had a significant flow but gradually disappeared due to tectonic changes and climatic shifts.

**Origin of the Name "Bharat"**
The name "Bharat" is derived from an ancient tribe mentioned in the Rig Vedic period known as the "Bharata" tribe. This name has been used historically to refer to the Indian subcontinent.
Rig Vedic Society
The Rig Vedic society, as depicted in the Rig Veda, had several distinct social, cultural, and religious characteristics:
Social Structure
**Patriarchal Society**: The society was male-dominated, with men holding primary authority in both family and community affairs.

**Varna System**: Social classification was based on occupation, not birth. There were four main varnas:
**Brahmins**: Priests and scholars.
**Kshatriyas**: Warriors and rulers.
**Vaishyas**: Merchants and farmers.
**Shudras**: Servants and laborers.

**Marriage Practices:**
**Monogamy**: Practiced among the lower varnas.
**Polygamy**: Practiced among the higher varnas, especially among the Kshatriyas.
Social Customs

**No Child Marriage**: There was no practice of child marriage during the Rig Vedic period.
**No Sati**: The practice of sati (the self-immolation of a widow on her husband's pyre) was not prevalent in Rig Vedic society.
Religious Practices
**Focus on Prayers**: The society was more focused on prayers and hymns for salvation rather than elaborate rituals and sacrifices.
**Natural Forces Worship**: Deities representing natural forces like Indra (thunder), Agni (fire), Varuna (rain), Vayu (wind), and Prithvi (earth) were worshipped.
**Less Ritualistic**: Compared to later periods, Rig Vedic religious practices were less ritualistic and more centered around hymns and prayers.
Rig Vedic Religion

During the Rig Vedic period, people worshipped various natural forces, each represented by a specific deity. The names of these gods and their associated natural elements are as follows:
**Indra**: God of Thunder
**Prithvi**: Goddess of Earth
**Vayu**: God of Wind
**Agni**: God of Fire
**Varuna**: God of Rain

**Indra:** Indra was the most important god of the Rig Vedic period. He was revered as the king of the gods and the deity of thunder and war. Indra was believed to be a powerful warrior who protected the people from their enemies and ensured victory in battles.

**Agni:** The second most important god was Agni. He was the god of fire and was central to various rituals and sacrifices. Agni was seen as the mediator between humans and gods, carrying offerings to the deities through fire.
Later Vedic Period Society

The Later Vedic period saw significant changes and developments in social, cultural, and religious practices compared to the Early Vedic period. Here are the key characteristics of Later Vedic society:
Social Structure

**More Rigid Varna System**:
The varna system became more rigid and stratified. 
Social classification, which was initially based on occupation, gradually became hereditary, i.e., based on birth.
Patriarchal Society

**Male Domination**:
The society continued to be patriarchal, with men holding primary authority in family and social affairs.
Women's roles were more restricted compared to the Early Vedic period.
Marriage and Social Customs

**Child Marriage**:
The practice of child marriage began to emerge during the Later Vedic period.

**Sati**:
The practice of sati (the self-immolation of a widow on her husband's funeral pyre) also started to appear, although it was not widespread.
Religious Practices

**Increased Ritualism**:
There was a significant increase in the importance of rituals and sacrifices.
Elaborate rituals conducted by Brahmins became central to religious practices.

**Priestly Dominance**:
The Brahmins gained more prominence and power due to their control over religious rituals and knowledge.
Later Vedic Gods

The Later Vedic period saw an evolution in the pantheon of deities worshipped and the nature of religious practices. Here are the key points regarding the gods and religious beliefs of the Later Vedic period:
Shift in Deities and Religious Focus

**Prominence of New Deities**:
Deities like Vishnu and Rudra (later associated with Shiva) became more prominent. 
The focus shifted from the nature gods of the Early Vedic period, like Indra and Agni, to more complex and abstract deities.
Important Deities

The main gods during the later vedic period were
1. Prajapati: the creator
2. Vishnu: the protector
3. Rudra: the destroyer
**Prajapati**: Prajapati, the lord of creatures, became an important deity associated with creation. He was often identified with Brahma, the creator god in later Hindu tradition.

**Vishnu**: Initially a minor deity in the Rig Veda, Vishnu gained prominence in the Later Vedic texts. He was associated with the preservation and maintenance of the universe. Vishnu's role as a protector and sustainer of life became more pronounced.

**Rudra/Shiva**: Rudra, a relatively minor deity in the Early Vedic period, evolved into a significant god in the Later Vedic period. He was associated with storms, death, and destruction but also had benevolent aspects. Rudra later became identified with Shiva, one of the principal deities in Hinduism.

children.title: [[Jainism]]
children.text: [[Jainism]]
The decline of Brahmanism (early Hinduism) and the rise of Jainism and Buddhism in ancient India can be attributed to several factors:

1. **Social Inequality and Rigidity**: Brahmanism was associated with a rigid social hierarchy (caste system) that often resulted in oppression and discrimination. Jainism and Buddhism offered more egalitarian and inclusive spiritual paths, attracting those seeking alternatives to the caste-based social order.

2. **Doctrinal Differences**: Jainism and Buddhism presented teachings that differed significantly from Brahmanism. For instance, they emphasized non-violence (ahimsa) and the idea of achieving liberation (moksha) through personal effort rather than rituals and sacrifices performed by Brahman priests.

3. **Appeal to the Masses**: Both Jainism and Buddhism appealed to a wider audience beyond the Brahmin and Kshatriya elites. They offered teachings that resonated with common people, promoting ethical conduct, compassion, and personal spiritual growth.

4. **Critique of Ritualism**: Jainism and Buddhism criticized the elaborate rituals and sacrifices central to Brahmanical practices. They advocated simpler, more introspective spiritual practices that focused on inner transformation rather than external rites.

5. **Support from Rulers**: Some rulers, dissatisfied with the dominance of Brahmanical priests, patronized Jainism and Buddhism. This royal patronage provided these religions with resources and opportunities for growth and dissemination.

The school of thoughts that does not follow Vedas are called as Heterodox school. The three main heterodox schools are:
1. Jainism 
2. Buddhism
3. Ajivika

**1. Jainism:**
Traditionally attributed to **Rishabhanatha** (Adinatha) as the first Tirthankara. 
**Mahavira** (Vardhamana) is the 24th Tirthankara who significantly formalized Jain teachings.

**Important rulers who were followers of Jainism:**
**Bimbisara**, founder of Haryanka dynasty, Magada empire
**Chandragupra Maurya**, founder of Maurya dynasty.

**2. Buddhism:**
Founder: Siddhartha Gautama, known as the Buddha, who founded Buddhism in the 5th century BCE.

**Important rulers who were followers of Jainism:**
**Ajatashatru**, ruler of Haryanka dynasty, Magadh empire
**Ashoka**, ruler of Maurya dynasty
**Kanishka**, ruler of Kushana dynasty.

**3. Ajivika:**
Founder: Makkhali Gosala. 
The Ajivikas were known for their doctrines of determinism and rejection of the notion of karma and free will.

**Important rulers who were followers of Jainism:**
**Bindusara**, ruler of Maurya dynasty

The founder(Gurus) of are called as  Tirthankaras.
1. Rishabanatha (symbol: bull)
2. Ajitanatha (symbol: Elephant)
..
23rd. Prasavanatha (symbol: Snake (Serpent) or Cobra)
24th. Vardhamana Mahavira (Lion)
Both Buddha and Mahavira was born in Kshatriya caste, and both spread his teachings in Prakrit language. Both Mahavira and Buddha are contemporaries ( though Jainism comes first than Buddhism)

The **Triratnas** (Three Jewels) of Jainism are fundamental principles that guide practitioners on the path to liberation. They are:
1. Right faith
2. Right knowledge
3. Right conduct

**1. Right Faith (Samyak Darshana)**:
Developing a correct understanding and belief in the fundamental truths of Jainism. This includes recognizing the nature of the soul, the reality of karma, and the teachings of the Tirthankaras. Right faith is the foundation for spiritual progress.

**2. Right Knowledge (Samyak Jnana)**:
Gaining accurate and thorough knowledge of Jain teachings, scriptures, and philosophy. This involves understanding the nature of reality, the principles of karma, and the path to liberation. Right knowledge helps in making informed decisions and practicing Jain principles correctly.

**3. Right Conduct (Samyak Charitra)**:
Following ethical and moral behavior as outlined by Jain teachings. This includes adhering to the Five Vows (Ahimsa, Satya, Asteya, Aparigraha, Brahmacharya) and living a life of non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, non-possessiveness, and celibacy. Right conduct ensures that one’s actions align with spiritual goals.
Five Vows of Jainism:

**Ahimsa (Non-Violence)**:
Avoiding harm to all living beings through thought, word, and action. It is the most fundamental vow and central to Jain practice.

**Satya (Truthfulness)**:
Commitment to truth and honesty in speech and conduct. One must avoid deceit and falsehood.

**Asteya (Non-Stealing)**:
Not taking anything that is not freely given. This vow extends beyond material possessions to include ideas and resources.

**Aparigraha (Non-Possessiveness)**:
Renunciation of material and emotional attachments. This vow emphasizes simplicity and non-attachment to worldly possessions.

**Brahmacharya (Chastity)**:
Practice of celibacy and control over sexual desires. This vow was formalized by Mahavira and is central to the ascetic life.
This was said to be added by 24th Tirthankara Vardhamana Mahavira.
**Karma**:

**Concept**: In Jainism, karma is seen as a form of subtle matter that binds to the soul due to one's actions, thoughts, and intentions. It affects one's cycle of birth and rebirth (samsara). The accumulation of karma determines future experiences and existence in the cycle of reincarnation.
**Liberation**: To achieve liberation (moksha), one must purify the soul by removing accumulated karma through right conduct, right knowledge, and right faith.
**Soul (Jiva)**:
**Concept**: Every living being has a soul (jiva) which is eternal and fundamentally pure. The soul undergoes cycles of birth and rebirth due to the accumulation of karma.
**Liberation**: The ultimate goal is to liberate the soul from the cycle of birth and rebirth and achieve a state of eternal bliss and freedom.

**Concept**: Jainism does not believe in a creator god or a personal god who controls the universe. Instead, it emphasizes the individual's journey toward liberation through self-effort and ethical living. The focus is on understanding the nature of the soul and the universe through philosophical inquiry and personal discipline.
**1. Shvetambara (White-Clad)**:

**Characteristics**:
**Clothing**: Monks and nuns wear white robes.
**Beliefs**: Shvetambara sect believes that women can achieve liberation and that Mahavira's teachings can be interpreted with some flexibility.
**Scriptures**: They adhere to the Agamas, the canonical texts of Jainism.
**2. Digambara (Sky-Clad)**:

**Characteristics**:
**Clothing**: Monks go naked (sky-clad) as a symbol of renunciation and detachment from material possessions.
**Beliefs**: Digambara sect holds that women cannot attain liberation in their current form and that absolute asceticism is necessary for enlightenment. They also believe in the necessity of the original teachings being preserved without alteration.
**Scriptures**: They follow a different set of scriptures and texts compared to the Shvetambaras.

children.title: [[Buddhism]]
children.text: [[Buddhism]]
The decline of Brahmanism (early Hinduism) and the rise of Jainism and Buddhism in ancient India can be attributed to several factors:

1. **Social Inequality and Rigidity**: Brahmanism was associated with a rigid social hierarchy (caste system) that often resulted in oppression and discrimination. Jainism and Buddhism offered more egalitarian and inclusive spiritual paths, attracting those seeking alternatives to the caste-based social order.

2. **Doctrinal Differences**: Jainism and Buddhism presented teachings that differed significantly from Brahmanism. For instance, they emphasized non-violence (ahimsa) and the idea of achieving liberation (moksha) through personal effort rather than rituals and sacrifices performed by Brahman priests.

3. **Appeal to the Masses**: Both Jainism and Buddhism appealed to a wider audience beyond the Brahmin and Kshatriya elites. They offered teachings that resonated with common people, promoting ethical conduct, compassion, and personal spiritual growth.

4. **Critique of Ritualism**: Jainism and Buddhism criticized the elaborate rituals and sacrifices central to Brahmanical practices. They advocated simpler, more introspective spiritual practices that focused on inner transformation rather than external rites.

5. **Support from Rulers**: Some rulers, dissatisfied with the dominance of Brahmanical priests, patronized Jainism and Buddhism. This royal patronage provided these religions with resources and opportunities for growth and dissemination.

**Real Name**: Buddha's real name was **Gautama Siddhartha**.
**Birth**: He was born in Lumbini, Kapilavastu, which is present-day **Nepal**, around **563-480 BCE** (exact dates vary in historical records).
**Caste**: He was born into the **Kshatriya** caste.

**Parents**:
**Father**: His father was **Suddhodana**, the king of the Sakya clan.
**Mother**: His mother was **Maya Devi**, who died shortly after his birth.
**Upbringing**: After his mother's death, he was raised by his **aunt**, **Pajapati Gotami**.

**Marriage and Son**:
At the age of 16 he married **Yashodhara**.
They had a son named **Rahula**.

**Renunciation**: He left his palace and family at the age of **29** in search of spiritual enlightenment.
**Enlightenment**: After **6 years** of intense meditation and ascetic practices, he attained enlightenment at **Bodh Gaya** at the age of **35**.
**Death**: Buddha passed away at the age of **80** in **Kushinagar**.
Five Important Events in the Life of Buddha

**1. Birth (Janma):**
Born in 563 BCE (according to traditional accounts) in Lumbini, Kapilavastu (in present-day Nepal).
Symbol: Lotus

**2. Renunciation (mahābhiniṣkramaṇa):**
Renounced worldly life at the age of 29.
Symbol: Horse

**3. Enlightenment (Nirvana):**
Attained enlightenment at the age of 35 at Bodh Gaya, Bihar, under the Bodhi Tree, near the Niranjana River.
Symbol: Bodhi Tree

**4. First Sermon (Dharmachakra Parivartana):**
Location: Sarnath, near Varanasi.
Symbol: Wheel (Dharmachakra)

**5. Death (Mahaparinirvana):**
Passed away at the age of 80, around 483 BCE, at Kusinagar, in UP.
Symbol: Stupa

Important Stupas:
**Sanchi Stupa:** Located in Madhya Pradesh, commissioned by Emperor Ashoka. 
It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

**Shanti Stupa:** Located in Ladakh, built as a symbol of peace.

data.text: When Siddhartha Gautama, who later became known as the Buddha, ventured out of his palace for the first time, he encountered four sights that profoundly influenced his path to enlightenment. These sights are known as the "Four Passing Sights" and are central to the story of his awakening. Here’s a simple explanation:

children.text:
**1. An Old Man**:
**What He Saw**: An elderly man, frail and bent with age.
**Impact**: Siddhartha realized the inevitability of aging and that everyone, including himself, would grow old.

**2. A Sick Man**:
**What He Saw**: A person suffering from illness, writhing in pain.
**Impact**: He understood that sickness is a part of life and that anyone can fall ill at any time.

**3. A Dead Man**:
**What He Saw**: A corpse being carried for cremation.
**Impact**: Siddhartha confronted the reality of death, recognizing that it is an unavoidable end for all living beings.

**4. A Holy Man (Ascetic)**:
**What He Saw**: A wandering ascetic who had renounced worldly pleasures in search of spiritual enlightenment.
**Impact**: This sight inspired Siddhartha to seek a higher purpose and find a solution to the suffering caused by aging, sickness, and death.

The Four Noble Truths are fundamental teachings in Buddhism that were delivered by Siddhartha Gautama, the Buddha, after he attained enlightenment. These truths diagnose the problem of human suffering and provide a path to its cessation. Here they are explained simply:
1. The Truth of Suffering (Dukkha)

Life involves suffering and dissatisfaction. This includes not only the obvious suffering of pain, illness, and death but also the more subtle dissatisfaction and discomfort that pervades everyday life.
Example: Birth, aging, illness, and death are forms of suffering.
Separation from loved ones, not getting what one wants, and being attached to things that are impermanent.
2. The Truth of the Cause of Suffering (Samudaya)

The cause of suffering is craving or desire (Tanha) and ignorance. This craving is a thirst for pleasures, material goods, and immortality, all of which are transient and ultimately unsatisfying.
Example: Desire for sensual pleasures, desire for existence and becoming, and ignorance about the true nature of reality.
3. The Truth of the End of Suffering (Nirodha)

Suffering can end by eliminating its cause. This state of cessation of suffering is called Nirvana, which means the extinguishing of the fires of desire and ignorance.
Example: Achieving Nirvana means liberation from the cycle of birth, death, and rebirth (samsara).
4. The Truth of the Path to the End of Suffering (Magga)

The way to end suffering is through the Eightfold Path, which is a practical guide to ethical and mental development with the goal of freeing the individual from attachments and delusions; it ultimately leads to understanding the truth about all things.
**The Eightfold Path**:

**1. Right View**: Understanding the Four Noble Truths.
**2. Right Intention**: Commitment to ethical and mental self-improvement.
**3. Right Speech**: Speaking truthfully, avoiding slander, gossip, and harmful speech.
**4. Right Action**: Acting in ways that do not harm others, adhering to moral conduct.
**5. Right Livelihood**: Earning a living in a way that does not harm others and is ethically positive.
**6. Right Effort**: Cultivating positive states of mind and reducing negative states.
**7. Right Mindfulness**: Developing awareness of the body, feelings, mind, and phenomena.
**8. Right Concentration**: Developing the ability to focus the mind through meditation.
First Buddhist Council

The first Buddhist council was convened shortly after the passing of Buddha, around 483 BCE, at **Rajagaha** (modern-day Rajgir). 
It was patronized by King **Ajatasattu** of the Haryanka dynasty. 
The council was presided over by **Mahakassapa Thera**, one of Buddha's senior disciples. During this council, the teachings of Buddha were recited and compiled into the **Sutta Pitaka** (collection of discourses or teachings of Buddha) and **Vinaya Pitaka** (code of monastic discipline).
Second Buddhist Council

The Second Buddhist Council was held approximately 100 years after the death of Buddha, around 383 BCE, at **Vaishali**. It was patronized by **King Kalasoka** of the Shishunaga dynasty and was presided over by the senior monk **Sabbakami**. The council was convened to address and resolve disputes regarding monastic practices and discipline. The primary issue was the disagreement on the interpretation and adherence to the Vinaya (monastic code), with ten specific points of contention, known as the "Ten Points," being debated.
Third Buddhist Council

The Third Buddhist Council was held around 250 BCE, during the reign of Emperor **Ashoka**, at **Pataliputra** (modern-day Patna). The council was presided over by the elder monk **Moggaliputta Tissa**. 
It was convened to address and rectify the issues of doctrinal deviations and to standardize the teachings of Buddhism. The main agenda was to review and consolidate the Buddhist scriptures and to address the spread of sectarianism and misunderstandings that had arisen. The council resulted in the compilation and editing of the Buddhist texts, and the establishment of the **Theravada tradition**. 
The **Abhidhamma Pitaka**, which deals with Buddhist philosophy and the systematic analysis of teachings, was compiled during the Third Buddhist Council.
Fourth Buddhist Council

The Fourth Buddhist Council, convened in the 1st century CE during the reign of **Kanishka**, the Kushan emperor, took place in **Kashmir** and was presided over by the esteemed monk **Vasumitra**. This council was pivotal in addressing doctrinal disputes and consolidating the teachings of Buddhism. Its primary outcome was the compilation and standardization of the **Mahayana Buddhist** scriptures. The council marked a crucial development in Mahayana Buddhism by solidifying a unified canon and promoting the Mahayana tradition. Under Kanishka's patronage, the council played a significant role in the preservation and dissemination of Buddhist teachings across Central Asia, reflecting a period of doctrinal clarification and the expansion of diverse Buddhist practices.

**Nalanda University:**
Location: Nalanda, Bihar
Founded By: Kumaragupta I (Gupta Empire)
Establishment Year: Around 5th century CE

**Vikramashila University:**
Location: Near Bhagalpur, Bihar
Founded By: Dharmapala (Pala Empire)
Establishment Year: Around 8th century CE
