children.title: [[Magadha Empire]]
children.text: [[Magadha Empire]]

The Magadha Empire was a powerful and influential ancient kingdom located in the eastern region of India, roughly corresponding to modern-day Bihar and parts of neighboring states. It played a crucial role in the political and cultural history of India, particularly during the first millennium BCE.

**Geographical Location**: Magadha was situated in the fertile Gangetic plains, which contributed to its prosperity and strategic significance. Its location made it a key player in regional politics and trade.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FXpUo1A5utt.png?alt=media&token=5d1346a2-7052-44bc-953a-093d77f82e9e)

**Historical Significance**: The empire's rise marked the beginning of a series of powerful Indian dynasties that shaped the history of the Indian subcontinent. It is particularly noted for its role in the early development of major Indian religions and philosophies.

The three important dynasties of Magadha empire were
1. Haryanka dynasty
2. Shishunga dynasty
3. Nanda dynasty

**Time Period**: Around 600 BCE to 413 BCE.
**Capital**: Initially Rajagriha (modern-day Rajgir) and later Pataliputra (modern-day Patna).
Important Rulers: Bimbisara, Ajatashatru, Udayn

**1. Bimbisara**: 
He was the founder of the Haryanka dynasty.
He ruled from around 544 BCE to 492 BCE. 
He was contemporary of both Mahavira and Buddha. Though he was said to be a follower of Jainism but he was known for his patronage of both Buddhism and Jainism.

**2. Ajatashatru**: 
He was son of Bimbisara.
He ruled Magadha from approximately 492 BCE to 460 BCE. 
He is noted for his military conquests and the expansion of the Magadha kingdom.
He was contemporary Buddha, and he patronaged the first buddhist council in around 483 BC at its capital Rajagriha.

**3. Udayin**: 
Udayin succeeded Ajatashatru.
He is known for moving the capital of Magadha from Rajagriha to Pataliputra, thus establishing it as a prominent political and administrative center.

Time period: 413 BCE to 345 BCE.
Capital: Initially Rajgit, later Patliputra. 
Important Rulers: Shishunaga, Kalasoka

**1. Shishunaga**: 
He was the founder of the dynasty, Shishunaga, ruled from around 413 BCE to 396 BCE. 
Initially, he was an amatya (official) of the Magadha empire under the Haryanka dynasty.
He is credited with consolidating Magadha’s power.

**2. Kalkaraja**: 
The successor of Shishunaga, his rule was relatively short, from 396 BCE to 390 BCE.
In round 393 BC he patronaged the second buddhist council. 
He shifted the capital from Rajgir to Patliputra

Time period: 345 BCE to 322 BCE.
Capital: Pataliputra.
Important Rulers: Mahapadma Nanda and Dhana Nanda.

**1. Mahapadma Nanda**: 
He was the founder of the Nanda dynasty.
Mahapadma Nanda, ruled from around 345 BCE to 325 BCE. 
He is known for his military prowess and administrative reforms that further strengthened the Magadha Empire.

**2. Dhana Nanda**: 
He was successor to Mahapadma Nanda.
He ruled from approximately 325 BCE to 322 BCE. 
His rule was marked by increasing unpopularity, which eventually led to his overthrow.
It was during his Alexander of Greek invaded India in around 323 BC.
He was the last ruler of Nanda dynasty, as during his reign Chandragupta Maurya, with the help of Kautaliya, he was defeated and Mauryan empire was established.

Alexander the Great, the Macedonian conqueror, embarked on his campaign into India after establishing his empire in Persia and other regions. His invasion marked the easternmost expansion of his empire.

Areas conquered by Alexander during its eastern ward expansion:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FZINC5BEJDU.png?alt=media&token=3dd96460-727d-4142-ae57-8e074f3b15cf)
Key events during invasion of Indian subcontinent by Alexander

**King of Taxila**: 
Taxila was an ancient city in what is now modern-day Pakistan. The ruler of Taxila during Alexander's invasion was **Ambhi (or Omphis)**. He initially sought to ally with [[Alexander]], providing him with support in return for favor and protection.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FHZSPhbsNLU.png?alt=media&token=c64ee2b0-d979-41d0-aef1-17f5d5027615)

**Advance to the River Beas**: 
[[Alexander]]'s campaign took him through the northwestern regions of the Indian subcontinent. He advanced up to the **River Beas (also known as the Bias River)**. The crossing of the Beas marked the limit of Alexander’s advance into India, as his troops, exhausted and demoralized, refused to march further east.

**Fight with Porus**: 
The king of the region between the Jhelum and Chenab rivers, known as **Porus (Puru)**, resisted [[Alexander]]’s invasion. The battle between Alexander and Porus, known as the **Battle of the Hydaspes (326 BC)**, was a significant confrontation. Despite his defeat, Porus was treated with respect by Alexander. He was reinstated as the ruler of his territory and was even granted additional lands.

**Battle of the Hydaspes (326 BCE)**: 
The battle occurred near the **Hydaspes River (modern Jhelum River)**. It was a fierce confrontation where Alexander's forces, despite facing a well-organized army led by Porus, managed to secure victory. The battle is notable for the use of elephants in warfare, which were initially a challenge for Alexander's army.
Aftermath

**Magadha and Dhana Nanda**: After his campaign, Alexander did not proceed further into the Indian subcontinent. By the time Alexander's forces turned back, **Magadha** was under the rule of **Dhana Nanda** of the Nanda dynasty. Dhana Nanda’s kingdom was a powerful empire in eastern India. Alexander's campaign did not directly impact Dhana Nanda, but it set the stage for the eventual rise of the Maurya Empire.

children.title: [[Solar System]]
children.text: [[Solar System]]

data.text:
A collection of billions of stars is called a **galaxy**. There are billions of galaxies in the universe, each with different shapes e.g Spiral, Circular etc. 
The galaxy that contains our Sun is called the **Milky Way Galaxy** (or Aakash Ganga), and it is spiral in shape. The Milky Way was discovered by **Galileo**. At the center of the Milky Way Galaxy, there is a black hole known as **Sagittarius A**.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FCxY7cDubx3.png?alt=media&token=3f3c7429-b9fa-42a2-b0a7-6f1d3c91bbdc)

The study of the universe is called **Cosmology**. 
The objects in the universe are known as **celestial bodies**. The three main types of celestial bodies are stars, planets, and satellites.
**Stars:** These have their own heat and light, such as the Sun.
**Planets:** These are bodies that revolve around a star, such as Earth.
**Satellites:** These are bodies that revolve around a planet, such as the Moon.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FV729jD2PcN.png?alt=media&token=ca5aea40-bea8-4aaf-a451-6ed28ec32dc0)

Stars are celestial bodies that produce their own heat (energy) and light. Our Sun is a star in the Milky Way Galaxy. It is primarily composed of hydrogen (H) and helium (He). Inside the Sun, two hydrogen atoms come together and fuse to form helium in a process called fusion. This fusion occurs due to the high pressure and temperature in the Sun's core. The radiation (heat and light) from the Sun is a result of this fusion of hydrogen atoms into helium. Sunlight takes approximately 8 minutes to reach the surface of the Earth.
The nearest star to the Sun is called "**Proxima Centauri**".

A group of stars that forms a recognisable pattern in the night sky is called as **constellation** . These patterns are often named after mythological characters, animals, or objects. The two major constellations are Ursa Major and Ursa Minor.
**Ursa Major**, also known as the Great Bear, is one of the most well-known constellations. It is visible throughout the year in most of the northern hemisphere. 
**Ursa Minor**, also known as the Little Bear, is another prominent constellation. It includes Polaris, also known as the **North  (Pole)Star**, which is located almost directly above the North Pole.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F2CBFWgQONf.png?alt=media&token=e7903a1f-ed2c-4aeb-80b7-4fd6937f7deb)
{video:u2E4F9Yy0rk:7}

children.text:
The Sun and the planets that orbit it form the Solar System. There are eight planets that revolve around the Sun in elliptical orbits. 

The eight planets are: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. The first four planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars) are called terrestrial planets, while the last four (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune) are known as gas giants or Jovian planets. 

Between Mars and Jupiter, there is a region that contains numerous asteroids, known as the **Asteroid Belt**. In the Asteroid belt the largest astroid is **Ceres**
{video:libKVRa01L8:0}

All planets rotate counterclockwise (from top view) or from west to east (side view) except for Venus and Uranus, which rotate clockwise or from east to west. Since Earth rotates counterclockwise or from east to west, we observe the Sun rising in the east.

Largest planet: Jupiter
Smallest planet: Mercury
Fastest planet (revolution): Mercury (88 days)
Fastest planet (rotation): Jupiter (9 hours, 55 minutes)
Slowest planet (rotation): Venus (243 days)
Hottest planet: Venus

Size wise (ascending order): Mercury, Mars, Venus, Earth, Neptune, Uranus, Saturn, and Jupiter. Jupiter is the largest planet.
**Mercury:** Mercury is the nearest planet to the Sun. It is the fastest planet in terms of revolution around the Sun, taking only 88 days. It has no satellites.

**Venus:** Venus is the hottest planet because its atmosphere contains a lot of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. Venus is also called Earth's twin because it is similar in shape and size to Earth. It has no satellites. Uranus and Venus are the only planets that rotate from east to west, while the rest rotate from west to east.
The Venus is slowest (in rotation) planet on the solar system, and thus its day (243 earth day) is longer than it year(225 earth days).

**Earth:** Earth is the only planet in the Solar System where life exists. It is also called the "Blue Planet" due to its appearance from space. It has one satellite, the Moon. The earth is 150 million KM away from the Sun.

**Mars:** Mars is known as the "Red Planet" because of the presence of iron oxide (rust) in its soil, which gives it its reddish color. It has two satellites, Phobos and Deimos. The highest peak in the Solar System, Olympus Mons, is a volcano located on Mars.
**Jupiter:** It is the largest planet in the Solar System. It has highest number of satellites (92) known satellites, with Ganymede being the largest moon in the entire Solar System.
**Saturn:** It has 83 known satellites. Titan is the largest moon of Saturn.

The Earth revolves around the Sun in an elliptical orbit, which means that the distance between the Earth and the Sun changes throughout the year. Our earth completed one revolution around Sun in **265 days and 6 hours**, and thus after every four years we have one extra day in the month of Feburary and that year is called as **leap year**. This revolution is responsible for the changing seasons and various astronomical phenomena.

**Aphelion:** The point in Earth's orbit where it is farthest from the Sun. This occurs around early July 4th each year, and the distance is about 152 million KMs

**Perihelion:** The point in Earth's orbit where it is closest to the Sun. This occurs around early January 3rd each year, and the distance is about 147 million KMs.

On average the earth is 150 million KM away from the Sun.

The earth is tilted by 23.5 degree, and thus due to this tilting of earth on its plane we have the tropic of cancer (23.5 degree N) and tropic of capricorn (23.5 degree S)  latitudes. This is because at any time in the year the direct rays of earth falls on any latitude between tropic of cancer and capricorn, and thus the region between To cancer and To capricorn receives highest [[insolation]], and is called as **torrid region**.  
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2F4koIr-UM_T.png?alt=media&token=5ed06617-c314-4c3c-b9bf-a646f5ee4aac)

Latitudes:
90 degree N: North pole
66.5 degree N: Artic Circle
23.5 degree N: tropic of cancer
23.5 degree S: tropic of capricorn
66.5 degree S: Antarctic circle
90 degree S: South pole
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FDQv_j_O8is.png?alt=media&token=21247dfe-35a9-4954-8f43-a9ad92f9546d)

The earth is tilted by 23.5 degree, and thus due to this tilting of earth on its plane we have the tropic of cancer (23.5 degree N) and tropic of capricorn (23.5 degree S)  latitudes. This is because at any time in the year the direct rays of earth falls on any latitude between tropic of cancer and capricorn, and thus the region between To cancer and To capricorn receives highest insolation, and is called as **torrid region**.
**Watch Video** on solstice and equinox here (right side) {video:oa7z_xfbREo:25}

When the Suns rays falls direct on the tropic of cancer, it is called **summer solstice**, and it occurs on June 21, the longest day in the north hemisphere. It is called summer solstice because that time it is summer in norther hemisphere. 
June 21: national Yoga day, Summer Solstice

When the Suns rays falls direct on the tropic of Capricorn, it is called **winter solstice**, and it occurs on Dec 21, the shortest day (longest night) in the north hemisphere.  It is called winter solstice because that time it is winter in northern hemisphere.

When the vertical rays of Sun falls directly over equator it is called **equinox**, and it happens twice, once in March 21-22 (Spring season = Vernal (Spring) Equinox ) and once in Sept 22-23 (autum season = Autumnal (Fall) Equinox ). 
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FxQVW2CaUwz.png?alt=media&token=b9246bbc-e320-4fa6-abd7-a30c221facb7)
The the primary cause of the weathers i.e summer, autumm, winter and sprint is the revolution of earth (as well as the titled nature of the earth.)

data.text: Rotation of Earth around its won axis.

children.text: The Earth rotates on its axis once approximately every 24 hours. This rotation is from west to east, which is why the Sun appears to rise in the east and set in the west.
**Axial Tilt:** The Earth's axis is tilted at an angle of about 23.5 degrees relative to its orbital plane around the Sun. This tilt remains constant as the Earth orbits the Sun.
**Day and Night Cycle:** The primary cause of day and night is the Earth's rotation. As the Earth rotates, different parts of the surface move into and out of the Sun's light.
The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. It is the fifth largest moon in the Solar System and the largest relative to the size of its planet.
**Synchronous Rotation:** The [[moon]] takes the same amount of time to rotate on its axis as it does to orbit the Earth. This period is approximately 27.3 days.
**Same Face Always Seen:** Because the rotation period and the orbital period are the same, the same side of the Moon always faces the Earth. This phenomenon is known as tidal locking.

**New Moon:** During the new moon phase, the Moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun. The side of the Moon facing Earth is not illuminated by the Sun, making it invisible in the night sky.

**Full Moon:** The full [[moon]] phase occurs when the Earth is between the Moon and the Sun. The side of the Moon facing Earth is fully illuminated, making it appear as a bright, complete circle.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FXdFuqHlxqI.png?alt=media&token=04135d49-ea22-4b49-b01e-43f25b45cd7d)

**Apogee:** Apogee is the point in the Moon's elliptical orbit where it is farthest from the Earth. At apogee, the Moon appears smaller in the sky.
**Perigee:** Perigee is the point in the Moon's elliptical orbit where it is closest to the Earth. At perigee, the Moon appears larger in the sky.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FBsN_XCpyNM.png?alt=media&token=61ca0632-ef20-4988-981e-844608dff4ce)

**Supermoon:** A supermoon occurs when a full moon or a new moon coincides with perigee, the point at which the Moon is closest to the Earth. This results in the Moon appearing larger and brighter than usual.

**Micromoon:** A micromoon occurs when a full moon or a new moon coincides with apogee, the point at which the Moon is farthest from the Earth. This results in the Moon appearing smaller and dimmer than usual.

children.title: [[Structure of Earth]]
children.text: [[Structure of Earth]]

The Earth is composed of several distinct layers, each with its own physical and chemical properties. These layers can be broadly classified into the crust, mantle, and core. 
Each layer plays a crucial role in the dynamics of our planet, including geological processes such as plate tectonics and volcanism.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FvDeFPZn3zh.png?alt=media&token=5b44dc4d-6971-4aa2-9076-2b5503499751)
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FvDeFPZn3zh.png?alt=media&token=5b44dc4d-6971-4aa2-9076-2b5503499751)

The Earth is not a perfect sphere but an **oblate spheroid** or **geoid**. This means that it is slightly flattened at the poles and bulging at the equator. The average radius of the Earth is approximately **6,371 kilometers** (3,959 miles). 
Since the shape of the earth is not perfect sphere but is geoid shape, thus the radius at poles (~ 6357 km ) in less than the radius at the equator (~ 6378). And little large radius of equator is due to the equatorial bulge caused by the Earth's rotation.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FvDeFPZn3zh.png?alt=media&token=5b44dc4d-6971-4aa2-9076-2b5503499751)

**Geoid Shape of Earth:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2Fgv-FBqc9Od.png?alt=media&token=711eb478-33a4-4472-9d7a-e95e2187e0fa):**

The earth consists of three layers {video:VI-QMnwsns8:0}
1. Crust
2. Mental
3. Core 
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FjIVWF4xZIe.png?alt=media&token=630122e9-2bd4-46e8-8d39-a1849bd7a88d)
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FUdHLCF-dMn.png?alt=media&token=151e122e-dea6-4d36-b02e-6250b5235c24)
Crust {video:VI-QMnwsns8:194}
The Earth's crust is the outermost layer, which is solid in nature. It makes only around 1% of the earths volume  and is divided into two types:

**Continental Crust**:
The continental crust primarily composed of silicon (Si) and Alumunium (Al) (Si-Al). On average its thickness is about 35 km.

**Oceanic Crust**:
The oceanic crust primarily composed of silicon (Si) and magnesium (Mg) (Si-Mg). On average its thickness is about 5 km.
Mantle
After the crust the next layer is Mantel. The total width of the mental ranges from around 2900 KM after crust, making 84% of Earth's total volume.

The top layer of the mantle is solid. The three upper solid layers i.e continental crust, oceanic crust, and the solid upper part of the mantle, are collectively known as the **lithosphere**. The lithosphere is broken into several pieces called tectonic plates.

Beneath the lithosphere lies the **asthenosphere**. It is a viscous layer with a thickness ranging from 100 to 700 kilometers. This layer contains partially molten rock known as **magma**. When magma rises to the surface or within the crust, it is referred to as **lava**. Once lava cools and solidifies, it forms **igneous rock**. The asthenosphere is mainly composed of silicon (Si) and magnesium (Mg)
Both the asthenosphere and the rest of the mantle are primarily composed of **silicon (Si)** and **magnesium (Mg)**.
Core

The Earth's core is the innermost layer of the earth. The width (thickness) of the core is 3500 km, and it makes around 15% of the earths volume. It is divided into two parts i.e outer and inner core.

**Outer Core**:
The outer core primarily composed of liquid iron (Fe) and nickel (Ni) - (NiFe).
The outer core is responsible for generating the Earth's magnetic field due to its liquid state and the movement of molten metals.

**Inner Core**:
The inner core primarily composed of solid iron (Fe).
The inner core is solid due to the extremely high pressures despite the high temperatures.

children.title: [[Rocks]]
children.text: [[Rocks]]

data.text:
Watch video here: {video:ZVFsbCV5J3o:0} 
Video by [Harshit Dwivedi Education](https://www.youtube.com/@HARSHITDWIVEDIVIDEOS)

children.text: Rocks are naturally occurring solid aggregates of minerals, mineraloids, or organic materials. They form the Earth's crust and are classified based on their origin and formation process. There are three main types of rocks: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. Each type has distinct characteristics and forms through different geological processes.

The topmost liquid viscous layer of the mantle is called the **asthenosphere**, and the liquid viscous material in this layer is known as **magma**. When magma rises and reaches the Earth's crust, it is referred to as **lava**. When lava solidifies, it forms **igneous rock**. Because igneous rocks are formed from magma, they are also known as **primary rocks**. Common igneous rock examples are **granite** and **basalt**.
The igneous rocks are categorised into two main types based on their formation location i.e intrusive and extrusive
**1. Intrusive Igneous Rocks**

**Formation:** These rocks form when magma solidifies beneath the Earth's crust. This type of igneous rock is known as **intrusive igneous rock** or **plutonic rock**. 

**Granite** is a common example of an intrusive igneous rock.

**Characteristics:** The solidification process occurs slowly underground, allowing large crystals to form. As a result, intrusive igneous rocks typically have a coarse-grained texture and are often large in size.
**2. Extrusive Igneous Rocks**

**Formation:** These rocks form when magma reaches the Earth's surface and solidifies quickly. This type of igneous rock is known as **extrusive igneous rock** or **volcanic rock**, and **Basalt** is a common example of an extrusive igneous rock.

**Characteristics:** The rapid solidification on the surface results in smaller crystals and a finer-grained texture compared to intrusive rocks. Extrusive igneous rocks are generally smaller in size compared to their intrusive counterparts.

Example of Igneous Rocks:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FR8wuP8MJ0X.png?alt=media&token=67e73bf9-e414-4260-98f8-8881fe821a1d)

**Formation:** Sedimentary rocks form from the accumulation and compaction of sediments, which may include mineral fragments, organic material, and chemical precipitates. They often form in layers over time.
**Clastic Sedimentary Rocks:** Formed from fragments of other rocks that have been cemented together. Example: Sandstone.
**Organic Sedimentary Rocks:** Formed from the accumulation of organic material. Example: Coal.

**Chemical Sedimentary Rocks:** Formed from the precipitation of minerals from solution. Example: Limestone. 
Chemical Sedimentary Rocks commonly contains fossils, however, the Clastic Sedimentary Rocks and Chemical Sedimentary Rocks can sometimes contain fossils, though it is less common:

**Characteristics:**
1. Often have a layered appearance.
3. The organic igneous rocks may contain **fossils**, as they often form in environments where organisms can be preserved.

Example of Sedimentary Rocks:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FyrLw2MCMBE.png?alt=media&token=11882db0-f255-4f37-80c5-dc4bd8adc35f)

*Formation:** Metamorphic rocks form from the transformation of existing rocks (igneous, sedimentary, or other metamorphic rocks) due to high temperature, pressure, or chemically active fluids. This process is known as metamorphism.
**Foliated Metamorphic Rocks:** Characterized by parallel layers or bands of minerals. Example: Schist.
**Non-Foliated Metamorphic Rocks:** Do not exhibit layering but are composed of interlocking mineral crystals. Example: **Marble**.

*Characteristics:**
1. Typically show evidence of deformation, such as foliation or banding.
2. Can be classified by their mineral composition and texture, which results from the metamorphic process.
3. Each type of rock plays a crucial role in the Earth's geology and provides valuable information about the Earth's history and processes.

Examples of Metamorphic Rocks:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FwMZlyqpvK9.png?alt=media&token=6d3eb33e-a5ca-41e4-ba0a-3596cb37ab08)

children.title: [[Earthquake]]
children.text: [[Earthquake]]

An earthquake is the shaking of the Earth's surface caused by the sudden release of energy in the Earth's lithosphere. This release of energy creates seismic waves that propagate through the Earth, causing ground shaking and sometimes significant damage.
Earthquakes are primarily caused by:

**Tectonic Plate Movements:** Most earthquakes occur due to the movement of tectonic plates. The Earth's lithosphere is divided into several large plates that float on the semi-fluid asthenosphere below. The boundaries where these plates interact are prone to earthquakes.
**Convergent Boundaries:** Plates collide or move toward each other.
**Divergent Boundaries:** Plates move apart from each other.
**Transform Boundaries:** Plates slide past each other horizontally.
**Volcanic Activity:** Earthquakes can also be triggered by volcanic activity, where magma movement within a volcano can cause the surrounding rocks to crack and produce seismic waves.
**Human Activities:** Certain human activities, such as mining, reservoir-induced seismicity (due to the filling of large reservoirs), and hydraulic fracturing (fracking), can induce earthquakes.
Seismic waves are the energy waves that travel through the Earth during an earthquake. They are classified into two main types: {video:uA_OLKfQpYA:90}
**Body Waves:** These waves travel through the Earth's interior.

**Primary Waves (P-Waves):** These are compressional waves that move faster than other seismic waves and are the first to be detected by seismographs. They cause particles in the Earth to move back and forth in the same direction as the wave.
S waves can passes through both liquid and solid medium.

**Secondary Waves (S-Waves):** These are shear waves that move slower than P-waves and are the second to be detected. They cause particles to move perpendicular to the direction of the wave. 
S waves can only passes through solid medium.

**Surface Waves:** These waves travel along the Earth's surface and usually cause more damage than body waves due to their larger amplitude and longer duration. It is the surface waves that causes most destrution during earthquake

Shadow zones refer to areas on the Earth's surface where seismic waves from an earthquake are not detected by seismographs. These zones occur due to the varying speeds and paths of seismic waves as they travel through the Earth’s interior, which is composed of different layers with varying densities and elastic properties.

Watch shadow zone animation {video:7eeqzRUg4DU:0}
Shadow Zones for P-Waves (Primary Waves):

**Nature of P-Waves:** Primary waves (P-waves) are compressional waves that travel through both solid and liquid materials. They move faster than S-waves and are the first to be detected by seismographs.

As P-waves travel through the Earth, they experience refraction at boundaries between different layers (e.g., crust-mantle boundary and mantle-core boundary) because their speed changes with the material's density and elasticity.
P-waves are refracted (bent) as they pass through the Earth's core, which has a liquid outer layer. This bending causes P-waves to be detected only in certain regions.

**P-Wave Shadow Zone:** The shadow zone for P-waves is found between approximately 104° and 140° from the earthquake's epicenter. This is because P-waves are refracted by the Earth's liquid outer core, creating a zone where no direct P-wave arrivals are detected.
Shadow Zones for S-Waves (Secondary Waves):
**Nature of S-Waves:** Secondary waves (S-waves) are shear waves that only travel through solid materials. They move slower than P-waves and are detected after P-waves.
S-waves do not travel through the Earth's liquid outer core, which creates a significant shadow zone.

**S-Wave Shadow Zone:** The shadow zone for S-waves is found beyond approximately 104° from the earthquake's epicenter. This zone is much larger compared to the P-wave shadow zone and extends to about 180° because S-waves are completely blocked by the liquid outer core.

Description of shadow zones:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FCtp1KU1cJ8.png?alt=media&token=85c555ac-bfdd-4786-971b-cbe0c8e7252f)

Earthquakes are measured in terms of their magnitude and intensity. Two main scales are used to assess these aspects: the **Richter scale** (for magnitude) and the **Mercalli scale** (for intensity). Additionally, **seismographs** are used to record and analyze seismic activity.

Output of a seismograph:
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2FUqoLMLPhqq.png?alt=media&token=962e3f00-1b66-4146-a17e-4e4c368a9dce)

children.title: [[Constituent Assembly]]
children.text: [[Constituent Assembly]]

The constitution assembly is a body that was constituted to draft a constitution. It represents diverse segments of society, including various political ideologies, regions, ethnicities, and interests, ensuring the constitution reflects the nation's pluralistic character. Members often include legal experts, scholars, and representatives with deep knowledge of constitutional law and governance, facilitating informed deliberations and decisions.

M.N. Roy, a communist, in 1934 for the first time suggested for making a constitution assembly to draft a constitution for India. The Indian national congress held its session at Lucknow in April 1936 presided by Jawaharlal Nehru. The official demand for a Constituent Assembly was raised and the Government of India Act, 1935 was rejected as it was an imposition on the people of India.

**August Offer 1940:** In August 1940 the British government for the first time agreed to constitute a constitutent assembly, with mainly Indias, to draft a constitution for India. But Indiasn rejected this offer.

**Cripps Mission 1942:** In 1942 the British government, via Cripps mission, agreed to constitute a constituent assembly with only India's, but again the proposal was rejected by Indians because of the issue of dominion status.

**Cabinet Mission Plan (1946)**: The British government sent the Cabinet Mission to India in 1946 to discuss the transfer of power. The mission proposed a plan to form a Constituent Assembly to draft a new constitution, and this proposal was accepted by Indians (or INC). Thus the constituent assembly was formed in 1946 as per the recommendation of the cabinet mission plan.

**Elections for Constituent Assembly** The Assembly, as per Cabinet Mission Plan, consisted of 389 members in which 296 were from British Provinces and 92 were from Princely States. The constituent assembly has both elected as well as nominated members. The elected members, from British provinces, were chosen indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies. The nominated members, from princely states, were nominated by the princes.

The election for the Constituent Assembly of India was held in June 1946, and the process of selecting members completed in November 1946. After the completion of this process, the elected members of the Constituent Assembly convened for their first meeting on December 9, 1946. This assembly was tasked with drafting the Constitution of India, which would eventually come into effect on January 26, 1950, marking India's transition to a sovereign republic.

**December 09 1946:** On this date, the members of the constituent assembly met for the first time. The first sitting of the constituent assembly was presided by Dr. Sachiananda Sinha, the oldest member in the assembly.

**December 11 1946:** On this date, elections for the post of president and vice president of the assembly were held, and Dr. Rajander Prasad elected as president, and both H.C. Mukherjee and V.T. Krishnamachari were elected as the Vice-Presidents of the Assembly. In other words, the Assembly had two Vice-Presidents at that time.
Note: VT Krishnamachari (vice president) and TT Krishnamachari (member of drafting committee) are two different persons.

**December 13 1946:** On this date Jawaharlal Nehru moved( also prepared) the objective resolution. This objective resolution was passed unanimously by the assembly on January 22, 1947. Later, on the last working day of the constituent assembly i.e January 24, 1950 thus objective resolution, with some amendments, adopted as the preamble of the constitution.
**November 26, 1949**: The Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution. This date is mentioned in the preamble, and thus due to this reason "Nov 26" is celebrated as the constitution day in India.

**January 24, 1950**: This was the last working day of the Constituent Assembly. On this day, the Preamble, National Anthem, and National Song were adopted.
Note: National flag was adopted on July 22, 1947
**January 25, 1950**: The Election Commission of India was appointed. This day is celebrated as National Voters' Day.

**January 26, 1950**: The Constitution came into force. Dr. Rajendra Prasad took oath as the first President of India, replacing the Governor-General as the head of state. Since the President is indirectly elected, India became a republic on this day. Republic means a state where the head of state is elected. And now the head of the state is elected by Indians, and on this day India became a Republic state.

Before Aug 15 1947: India was a **British colony**

Aug 15, 1947 to Jan 26, 1950: During this period, India was a **Dominion of the British Commonwealth**. This means that while India was independent in its governance, it recognized the British monarch (represented by the Governor-General of India) as its head of state and was a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. The then governor-general of British India i.e Lord Mountbatten, continued as the first governor-general of free India after Independence, and after him Rajagopalachari, became the first indian governor-general of India.

On Jan 26 1950: India became a **Sovereign, Democratic, Republic** nation state. As on this day the head of the state of India i.e president (who was indirectly elected) took oath, and thus India became a republic state.
[[When]] did India became a part of British Commonwealth?
Major Committees of Constituent Assembly
1. Union Powers Committee – Jawaharlal Nehru
2. Union Constitution Committee – Jawaharlal Nehru
3. Provincial Constitution Committee – Sardar Patel
4. Drafting Committee – Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
5. Advisory Committee on Fundamental Rights, Minorities and Tribal and Excluded Areas – Sardar Patel
Drafting committee

The Drafting Committee was the most important committee of the constituent assembly formed on August 29, 1947. It was tasked with preparing a draft of the new Constitution for independent India.
It has **7 members** and **Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was appointed as the Chairman** of the Drafting Committee. He is often referred to as the principal architect of the Indian Constitution.

Members of Drafting committee:

Chairman:
Dr. BR Ambedkar

Other members:
1. N Gopalaswamy Ayyangar
2. Muhammad Saadullah
3. Alladi Krishnaswami Ayyar
4. KM Munshi
5. BL Mittar substituted by N Madhava Rao following his resignation on health issues
6. Dr. DP Khaitan (died in 1948 and was substituted by TT Krishnamachari)
Note: VT Krishnamachari (vice president) and TT Krishnamachari (member of drafting committee) are two different persons.

**Muhammad Saadullah** was elected to the Constituent Assembly from Assam. He was one of 28 Muslim League members who attended the proceedings of the Assembly and was the only member from the Muslim League to sit on the Drafting Committee.

Therefore, the Constitution as adopted on November 26, 1949, included 22 Parts, 395 Articles and 8 Schedules. The Preamble was adopted later on January 24 1950. The constitution came into force on January 26, 1950 and that constitution is called as "original [[constitution]]". Thus the original constitution consisted of a preamble, 22 parts, 395 article and 8 scheduled. 

As of today ( July 2024) the Indian Constitution has 448 articles, 25 parts, 12 schedules, and 106 amendments

children.title: [[Preamble]]
children.text: [[Preamble]]

The American Constitution was the first to begin with a Preamble. Many countries, including India, followed this practice. The term ‘preamble’ refers to the introduction or preface to the Constitution. It contains the summary or essence of the Constitution.
N A Palkhivala, an eminent jurist and constitutional expert, called the Preamble as the ‘identity card of the Constitution.

The Preamble to the Indian Constitution is based on the **'Objectives Resolution'**, which was drafted and moved by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and adopted by the Constituent Assembly.
On **December 13, 1946**, Jawaharlal Nehru introduced the Objectives Resolution in the Constituent Assembly.
It was unanimously adopted by the Constituent Assembly on **January 22, 1947**.
On the last working day of the Constituent Assembly, **January 24, 1950**, the Objectives Resolution, with some amendments, was adopted as the Preamble to the Indian Constitution.

data.text:
Preamble: Borrowed from USA constitution
Idea of "JUSTICE" was borrowed from USSR constitution
Idea of "Republic, LIBERTY, EQUALITY, FRATERNITY" was borrowed from French constitution.

children.text: The Preamble reveals four ingredients or components:
Source of authority of the Constitution: The Preamble states that the Constitution derives its authority from the people of India.
Nature of Indian State: It declares India to be of a sovereign, socialist, secular democratic and republican polity.
Objectives of the Constitution: It specifies justice, liberty, equality and fraternity as the objectives.

Date of adoption of the Constitution: is November 26, 1949. 
On this date constitution was adopted.
This date is mentioned in the preamble, and is celebrated as "national constitution day" in India.
Though the constitution was adopted on "Nov 26 1949" but it came into force two months later i.e on "January 26th 1950", and on this date India became a sovereign republic state.

data.text: PREAMBLE AS PART OF THE CONSTITUTION

children.text: As the constitution was adopted on Nov 26 1946, where as the preamble was adopted on Jan 24 1950, the last working day of the constitution, and thus one of the controversies about the Preamble is as to whether it is a part of the Constitution or not.

In the **Berubari case (1960)**, the Supreme Court said that the **Preamble is not a part of the constitution**, but it shows the general purposes behind the several provisions in the Constitution, and is thus a key to the minds of the makers of the Constitution. Thus the SC also held that "preamble can be used a guide for interpretation of the constitution".
In the **Kesavananda Bharati case (1973)**, the Supreme Court rejected the earlier opinion and held that **Preamble is a part of the Constitution**.

The question of whether the Preamble could be amended first arose in the landmark case of Kesavananda Bharati (1973). Initially, it was argued that the Preamble, not being a part of the Constitution, could not be amended. However, in the Kesavananda Bharati case, the Supreme Court held that the Preamble is indeed a part of the Constitution and can be amended, provided such amendments do not alter its basic structure.

Subsequently, in 1976, the Parliament amended the Preamble through the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976. This amendment introduced three new crucial terms into the Preamble: "SOCIALIST," "SECULAR," and "Integrity," thereby reflecting the evolving socio-political aspirations of the nation.

children.title: [[Citizenship]]
children.text: [[Citizenship]]

data.text: The Part-II (article 5-11) of the Indian Constitution deal with the concept of citizenship.

**Article 5**: Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution
Any person who was born in India or had either of their parents born in India, or who has been ordinarily resident in India for at least five years immediately preceding the commencement of the Constitution, is considered a citizen of India.

**Article 6**: Rights of citizenship of certain persons who have migrated to India from Pakistan
Persons who migrated to India from Pakistan before July 19, 1948, and have been resident in India since their migration, are considered citizens of India. For those who migrated after this date, they must have been registered as citizens.

**Article 7**: Rights of citizenship of certain migrants to Pakistan
Individuals who migrated to Pakistan after March 1, 1947, and returned to India under a permit for resettlement can be citizens of India if they meet certain conditions.

**Article 8**: Rights of citizenship of certain persons of Indian origin residing outside India
Persons of Indian origin residing outside India who hold citizenship of a country outside India can become citizens of India if they are registered by the diplomatic or consular representatives of India in the country where they are residing.

**Article 9**: Persons voluntarily acquiring citizenship of a foreign State not to be citizens
If a person voluntarily acquires the citizenship of any foreign state, they will no longer be a citizen of India.
It says that India adopts "single citizenship". 
India borrowed this feature from Canada constitution. 
India and Canada have single citizenship and on the other hand USA has dual citizenship i.e citizenship of centre as well as state. 
If an indian citizen accepts citizenship of any other country then he/she will lose his/her indian citizenship automatically.
**Article 10**: Continuance of the rights of citizenship

children.text: Every person who is or is deemed to be a citizen of India shall continue to be such a citizen, subject to the provisions of any law that Parliament may make.

data.text: **Article 11**: Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law

children.text: In the 7th schedule of the constitution the "citizenship" is a subject uder union list. The Parliament has the authority to make any provision regarding the acquisition and termination of citizenship and all other matters related to citizenship. In this regard the parliament enacted Citizenship Act 1955.
The Citizenship Act, 1955
The Citizenship Act, 1955 provides the law for acquisition and termination of Indian citizenship. Here’s a brief overview:
**Acquisition of Citizenship**:
**By Birth**: A person born in India is a citizen if at least one parent is a citizen of India.
**By Descent**: A person born outside India is a citizen if either parent is a citizen of India at the time of birth.
**By Registration**: Certain categories of persons, including persons of Indian origin who have been resident in India for seven years, can apply for citizenship by registration.
**By Naturalization**: A foreigner can acquire Indian citizenship by naturalization if they have resided in India for twelve years and meet other qualifications specified in the Act.
**By Incorporation of Territory**: If any new territory becomes part of India, the government may specify who among the people of the territory shall be citizens of India.
**Loss of Citizenship**:
**By Renunciation**: Any Indian citizen who is also a citizen or intends to become a citizen of another country can renounce their Indian citizenship.
**By Termination**: If a citizen voluntarily acquires the citizenship of another country, their Indian citizenship is automatically terminated.

**By Deprivation**: The government can deprive a person of their citizenship if it was acquired by fraud, or if the person has shown disloyalty to the Constitution, or has unlawfully traded with the enemy during war, among other grounds.

children.title: [[Fundamental Rights]]
children.text: [[Fundamental Rights]]

Fundamental Rights are enshrined in **Part III** of the Indian Constitution, from Articles 12 to 35. 
They are called as fundamental rights because they are **guaranteed** rights. 
They are **enforceable** by court ( supreme court under article 32, high court under article 226).
These rights are essential for the overall development of individuals and the preservation of human dignity. They form the cornerstone of India's democratic system and ensure that citizens can live a life of equality, freedom, and justice.
**Universal Application**: Fundamental Rights apply universally to all citizens, irrespective of race, religion, caste, gender, or place of birth.
**Justiciable**: These rights are enforceable by the courts, meaning individuals can approach the judiciary if they feel their rights are being violated.
**Non absolute** They are not absolute and the state can put reasonable restrictions.
**Protection Against State Action**: Fundamental Rights primarily act as a check against the arbitrary actions of the state and its organs.
**Negative and Positive Obligations**: Some rights place negative obligations on the state (to refrain from certain actions), while others impose positive obligations (to take specific actions).

The Constitution of India originally provided for seven Fundamental Rights. However, in 1978, the Right to Property was removed from Part III (Article 31) and moved to Part XII (Article 300A). As a result, there are currently six Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution. These rights are essential for ensuring individual liberties and maintaining the democratic framework of the country.

The Six Fundamental Rights are:
1. Right to Equality
2. Right to Freedom
3. Right Against Exploitation
4. Right to Freedom of Religion
5. Cultural and Educational Rights
6. Right to Constitutional Remedies

The "Right to Property" is no more a fundamental right.
**Right to Equality (Articles 14-18)**:
**Article 14**: Equality before law and equal protection of laws.
**Article 15**: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
**Article 16**: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.
**Article 17**: Abolition of untouchability.
**Article 18**: Abolition of titles except in military and academic.
**Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22)**:
**Article 19**: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.
**Article 20**: Protection in respect of conviction for offenses.
**Article 21**: Protection of life and personal liberty.
**Article 21A**: Right to free education for children between 6 to 14 age. It was added via 86th amendment 2002.
**Article 22**: Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases.
**Right Against Exploitation (Articles 23-24)**:
**Article 23**: Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

**Article 24: Prohibition of employment of children:**
This article explicitly prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 years in factories, mines, and other hazardous occupations. This provision is crucial for safeguarding the health, safety, and development of children, ensuring that they are not subjected to work environments that could be detrimental to their physical and mental well-being.
**Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28)**:
**Article 25**: Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion.
**Article 26**: Freedom to manage religious affairs.
**Article 27**: Freedom from payment of taxes for promotion of any religion.
**Article 28**: Freedom from attending religious instruction or worship in certain educational institutions.
**Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30)**:
**Article 29**: Protection of interests of minorities.
**Article 30**: Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions.
**Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)**:
**Article 32**: The right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
**Protection of Individual Liberties**: They safeguard individual freedoms and protect against state tyranny.
**Promotion of Social Justice**: They promote social equality and justice, essential for the progress of any democracy.
**Foundation of Democracy**: They provide a framework for a democratic society where the rule of law prevails.

children.title: [[DPSP]]
children.text: [[DPSP]]

The Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are guidelines for the government to follow when making laws. 
These principles are found in Part IV (Articles 36-51) of the Indian Constitution. 
They are borrowed from Ireland constitution.
Even though these principles can't be enforced by any court i.e non-enforceable, they are very important for governing the country. They aim to create conditions where everyone can live a good life. The DPSPs help the government to make laws and policies that aim to create a fair and just society. India borrowed the DPSP from Ireland constitution.

The DPSP is **not enforceable by law;** where as fundamental rights are-justiciable. Unlike the Fundamental Rights (FRs), the **scope of DPSP is limitless** and it protects the rights of a citizen and work at a **macro level.** DPSP consists of all the **ideals which the State should follow** and keep in mind while formulating policies and enacting laws for the country.

**Article 36:**
This article explains what the term "State" means in the context of DPSP. The term "State" includes the government and Parliament of India, the government and the legislature of each state, and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

**Article 37:** 
It says that the DPSPs are **not enforceable** by any court, but they are fundamental in the governance of the country. The government must keep these principles in mind while making laws. These principles aim at ensuring **socioe-conomic justice** to the people and establishing India as a Welfare State.

**Article 38: State to Secure a Social Order for the Promotion of Welfare of the People**
The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting a social order by** ensuring social, economic and political justice** and by [**minimising inequalities** in income, status, facilities and opportunities] ( [..] added via 44th amendment 1978)
(Socialist)

**Articles 39:** The State shall in particular, direct its policies towards securing:
> Right to an** adequate means of livelihood** to all the citizens.
> The** ownership and control of material resources** shall be organised in a manner to serve the common good.
> The State shall **avoid concentration of wealth in a few hands.**
> **Equal pay for equal work** for both men and women.
> The protection of the strength and health of the workers.
> Childhood and youth shall not be exploited.
(Socialist)

**Article 39A: Equal Justice and Free Legal Aid**
It was added via 42nd amendment act 1976
The government must ensure that the legal system promotes justice on the basis of equal opportunity. (Socialist)
**Article 40:** The government should take steps to **organize village panchayats** and give them powers and authority to function as units of self-government. (Ghandian)
**Article 41:** To secure the** right to work, to education and to public assistance** in cases of unemployment, **old age, sickness and disability.** (Socialist)
**Article 42:** The State shall make provisions for **securing just and humane conditions of work and for maternity relief.** (Socialist)

**Article 43: Living Wage, etc., for Workers**
The government should work to ensure that all workers get a decent wage, a good standard of living, and social and cultural opportunities. (Socalist)
It should also **promote cottage industries** in rural areas. (Ghandian)

**Article 43A: Participation of Workers in Management of Industries**
The government should take steps to ensure that workers have a say in the management of the industries where they work. This aims to improve worker-management relations and productivity.
It was added via 42nd amendment 1976

**Article 43B:** The government should work to promote the formation and functioning of **cooperative societies**. 
Article 43B encourages the government to support and promote cooperative societies. 
It was added via 97th amendment 2011

**Article 44:** The government should work towards creating a **Uniform Civil Code** for all citizens across the country, ensuring that all people are governed by the same set of civil laws, irrespective of their religion.

**Article 45:** To provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the **age of six years..
Earlier it was just "care", then in 2002 via 86th amendment act 2002 "education" was added

**Article 46: Promotion of Educational and Economic Interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Other Weaker Sections** 
The government should promote the **educational and economic interests** of the **weaker sections** of society, particularly the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, and **protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation**.

**Article 47: Duty of the State to Raise the Level of Nutrition and the Standard of Living and to Improve Public Health**
The government should work to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living of the people and improve public health. This includes efforts to prohibit the consumption of intoxicating drinks and drugs that are harmful to health.

**Article 48: Organisation of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry**
The government should take steps to **organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines**. (Liberal)
It should also preserve and improve the breeds of animals and **prohibit the slaughter of cows** and calves and other milch and draught cattle. (Gandhian)

**Article 48A: Protection and Improvement of Environment and Safeguarding of Forests and Wildlife**
The government should make efforts to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard the forests and wildlife of the country. (Liberal)
It was added via 42nd amendment act 1976

**Article 49: Protection of Monuments and Places and Objects of National Importance**
The government should protect historic monuments, places, and objects of artistic or historic interest from damage, disfigurement, destruction, or removal.

**Article 50: Separation of Judiciary from Executive**
The government should take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the state. This aims to ensure the independence of the judiciary. And this DPSP is a part of the basic structure. (Liberal)

**Article 51: Promotion of International Peace and Security**
The government should work to:
(a) Promote international peace and security.
(b) Maintain just and honorable relations between nations.
(c) Foster respect for international law and treaty obligations.
(d) Encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration.

SO far DPSP was amended four times:
1976: 42nd amendment, added 39(f), 39A, 42A, 48A
1978: 44th amendment, added 38(2)
2002: 85th amendment, amended 45
2011: 97th amendment, added 43B
The Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are categorized based on their content into three main groups:

**Socialist Principles (Articles 38, 39, 39A, 41, 42, 43)**:
These principles aim to establish social and economic justice in society. They include provisions for ensuring fair wages, adequate livelihood, equal pay for equal work, protection of children and youth, and improvement in public health.

**Gandhian Principles (Articles 40, 43, 46, 47, 48)**:
These principles are inspired by Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy and focus on rural development, prohibition of alcohol consumption, promotion of cottage industries, and the welfare of weaker sections of society, including Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

**Liberal Principles (Articles 44, 45, 48, 48A, 49, 50, 51)**:
These principles emphasize individual liberties, secularism, free and compulsory education for children, protection of monuments of national importance, separation of judiciary from the executive, promotion of international peace and security, and respect for international law and treaty obligations.

**Champakam Dorairajan case (1951)**:
In this case, the Supreme Court ruled that if there is any conflict between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles, Fundamental Rights take precedence.
It stated that Directive Principles must align with and be **subservient** to Fundamental Rights.
The Court also ruled that Parliament can amend Fundamental Rights through constitutional amendments.

**Golaknath case (1967)**:
The Supreme Court declared that Fundamental Rights cannot be amended by Parliament, even to implement Directive Principles.
This decision contradicted its earlier ruling in the 'Shankari Prasad case' (where SC said FRs can be amended by parliament).
**Kesavananda Bharati case (1973)**:

Overruling Golaknath, the Supreme Court held that Parliament has the power to amend any part of the Constitution. However, it established that Parliament cannot alter the "Basic Structure" of the Constitution. This case led to the removal of Right to Property (Article 31) from the list of Fundamental Rights.
**Minerva Mills case (1980)**:
The Supreme Court reaffirmed that Parliament can amend any part of the Constitution. It reiterated that the "Basic Structure" of the Constitution cannot be changed by Parliament.
These cases highlight the evolving interpretations by the Supreme Court regarding the balance between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles in India's constitutional framework.

children.title: [[Fundamental Duties]]
children.text: [[Fundamental Duties]]

The concept of Fundamental Duties was not originally present in the Indian Constitution but introduced later to emphasize civic responsibilities and uphold national integrity. These duties were recommended by the **Swaran Singh Committee** in 1976 and added via the **42nd Amendment Act of 1976**, which introduced a **new Part IVA and Article 51A** to the Constitution.

Initially, there were 10 Fundamental Duties enumerated under Article 51A (via 42nd amendment 1976). These duties were inspired by similar provisions in the constitutions of socialist countries like the USSR, reflecting a collective responsibility towards society and the nation. The 86th Amendment Act, 2002 added an 11th Fundamental Duty to Article 51A, which emphasizes the importance of parents or guardians ensuring that their children receive education between the ages of six and fourteen years.
**Origins:** Borrowed from the USSR constitution. They are not enforceable, but they highlight the role of citizens in fostering a harmonious and inclusive society.
**42nd Amendment (1976):** Significantly amended the Constitution to include Part IVA and Article 51A, outlining the initial 10 Fundamental Duties.
**86th Amendment (2002):** Introduced the 11th Fundamental Duty, underlining the obligation of parents towards educating their children.
The inclusion of Fundamental Duties aims to:
Foster a sense of responsibility and discipline among citizens.
Strengthen the social fabric and promote a sense of patriotism and nationalism.
Balance rights with duties, recognizing that the enjoyment of rights must be accompanied by responsibilities towards society and the nation.
1. To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag, and the National Anthem.
2. To cherish and follow the noble ideals that inspired the national struggle for freedom.
3. To uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India.
4. To defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so.
5. To promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood among all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic, and regional or sectional diversities.
6. To value and preserve the rich heritage of the country’s composite culture.
7. To protect and improve the natural environment, including forests, lakes, rivers, and wildlife, and to have compassion for living creatures.
8. To develop scientific temper, humanism, and the spirit of inquiry and reform.
9. To safeguard public property and to abjure violence.
10. To strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity, so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of endeavor and achievement.

11. To provide opportunities for education to children between 6-14 years of age and duty as parents to ensure that such opportunities are being awarded to their child.
This fundamental right was not there in 1976, but it was added later via 86th amendment 2002.

children.title: [[President]]
children.text: [[President]]

data.text: The president is the head of the country India. He is the first citizen of India. Since he president of India is the head of the state and he is elected thus India is a republic state. Republic means when the head of the state is elected one.

**Qualifications:**There are three qualifications required for running for the President election:
1. Should be an Indian citizen.
2. Should be above the age of 35 years.
3. Should be eligible to become a member of the Lok Sabha. 
(Article 58)

**Election:** The President is elected through indirect [[election]]. All the elected MPs of the Parliament and MLAs of the state legislative assembly take part in the election of the President, (Article 66). 
The election of president take place through secret ballot.
**Oath:** Once elected, the President takes oath before the chief justice of India or the senior most judge pf the supreme court. ( Article 60)

**Tenure:** The tenure of the President is five years. (Article 56)
He can be reappointed as many number of time, there is no bar on the election for presidentship. (Article 57)

**Disputes:** All disputes related to the election of the President and Vice President are referred to the Supreme Court, and the decision of the Supreme Court in this regard is final. Once the Supreme Court declares an election void, the person shall be disqualified from the office. (Article 71)
**Resignation:** The President, when resigning from office, writes to the Vice President. (vice versa)

**Impeachment:** The removal of the president is called as "impeachment". This feature we borrowed from USA constitution. The president is impeached from the house by the parliament.
(Article 61)

children.title: [[Vice President]]
children.text: [[Vice President]]

data.text: The Vice President is the second citizen of India (the first is the President). The office of the Vice President is borrowed from the U.S. Constitution.

children.text: 1. **Chairman of the Rajya Sabha:** The Vice President of India is the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha. This feature is borrowed from the USA, where the Vice President is the Chairman of the upper house of the US Congress, i.e., the Senate. (Article 64)
2. **Acting President:** The Vice President acts as the President when the sitting President is absent or when the office of the President is vacant. (Article 65)

data.text:
**Qualifications:**There are three qualifications required for running for the Vice President election:
1. Should be an Indian citizen.
2. Should be above the age of 35 years.
3. Should be eligible to become a member of the Rajya Sabha. (Article 66)

**Election:** The Vice President, like the President, is elected through indirect [[election]]. All the MPs of the Parliament take part in the election of the Vice President (same for the removal of the President). (Article 66). The election of vice president take place through secret ballot.

**Disputes:** All disputes related to the [[election]] of the President and Vice President are referred to the Supreme Court, and the decision of the Supreme Court in this regard is final. Once the Supreme Court declares an election void, the person shall be disqualified from the office. (Article 71)
**Oath:** Once elected, the Vice President takes oath before the President or any person appointed by him in this regard. (Article 69)

**Tenure:** The tenure of the Vice President is five years. It should be kept in mind that though the Vice President is the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha, his tenure is only five years, whereas Rajya Sabha members have a tenure of six years. (Article 67).

**Resignation:** The Vice President, when resigning from office, writes to the President. (vice versa) 
(Article 67)

**Removal:** Though all the MPs of the Parliament take part in the removal of the Vice President, the removal process of the Vice President initiates from the Rajya Sabha, where the removal motion is passed by an effective majority. Then it is referred to the Lok Sabha, where the removal motion is passed by a simple majority. Thus the rajya sabha has more say in the removal of the vice president.

Thus, in the removal of the President, both houses have equal power, but in the case of the Vice President, the Rajya Sabha has the upper hand. There are no grounds mentioned for the removal of the Vice President.

children.title: [[Governor]]
children.text: [[Governor]]

data.text:
The governor is the constitutional head of the state. He is the first citizen of the state. There can be one person acting as governor of more than one state or governor of a state and Lt. governor of a UT. 

He has dual role
1. He is the nominal head of the state (like president for centre)
2. He is an agent of the union government in the state.

**Appointment:** 
The governor is appointed by the president (Article 155). There are two conventions followed during the appointment of the governor which are
(a) He is not from the concerned state
(b) While appointing him, the chief minister of the concerned state is consulted. 
The President may transfer a Governor appointed to one state to another state for the rest of the term.  Further, a Governor whose term has expired may be reappointed in the same state or any other state

**Tenure** (Article 156).
The term of the governor is five years but he has no fixed tenure. He holds office during the pleasure of the president, thus the governor has no security of tenure. The president can remove the governor at any time, and there is no ground mentioned for his removal. 
A governor can hold office beyond his term of five years until his  successor assumes charge.

**Vacancy:**
The President can make such provision as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the governor in any contingency not provided for in the Constitution, for example, the death of a sitting governor.  Thus, the Chief Justice of HC concerned state high court may be appointed temporarily to discharge the functions of the governor of that state

**Qualification:** (Article 157)
There are two qualification to become the president.
1. He should be an indian citizen
2. He should have completed age of 35 year.

**Oath:** (Article 159)
The governor takes oath before the chief justice of high court or the senior most judge of the concerned high court.

**Condition of office:** (Article 158)
The Constitution lays down the following conditions for the the governor’s office:
1. He should not be a member of either House of Parliament or a House of the state legislature. If any such person is appointed as governor, he is deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as the governor.
2. He should not hold any other office of profit.
3. He is entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residence i.e he Raj Bhavan 
4. He is entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by  parliament.

**Rashtrapati Bhavan:** Official residence of the President of India
**Raj Bhavan:** Official residence of the Governors of Indian states
**Raj Niwas:** Official residence of the Lieutenant Governors or Administrators of Union Territories in India

**White house:** Official residence of the USA president
**Blue house:** Official residence and executive office of the President of South Korea.

children.title: [[Prime Minister]]
children.text: [[Prime Minister]]

data.text: In india the prime minister is the real head of the country (president is nominal head). Though in India are the executive actions are done in the name of the president (article 53) but the president has to function as per the aid and advice given by the council of ministers headed by the prime minister.

In india the prime minister is appointed by the president (Article 75). The leader of the party or coalition which has majority in the lok sabha is appointed as the prime minister by the president. And all other ministers are also appointed by the president on the advice of the prime minister. This PM and all other ministers hold office during the pleasure of the president and they don't have fixed tenure.

In India a minister, including prime minister, can be from either house of the parliament. Even a person who is not yet a member of parliament can become a minister but he has to become a member of either those within six months.

India borrowed the parliamentary system from Britain. In India prime minister can be from either house of the parliament, but in Britain the prime minister has to be a member of the lower house i.e house of common.

In india the legislature is called as parliament. It has two house, upper house i.e rajya sabha and lower house i.e lok sabha. The official name of rajya sabha is "council of states" and the official name of lok sabha is "house of the people". In Britain the upper house is called as house of lords and the lower house is called as the house of commons. In USA the legislature is called as US Congress, which has two houses, the upper house is called as Senate and the lower house is called as House of Representatives

The council of ministers headed by prime minister are collectively repsonsible to lok sabha. They sink and swim together. If a no cnfidance motion is passed the then whole council of ministers have to resign. The no confidence motion is introduced only in the lok sabha.

children.title: [[Attorney General]]
children.text: [[Attorney General]]

data.text: The attorney general is a constitutional office under article 76.
He is appointed by the president. He doesn't have any fixed tenure and holds office during the pleasure of the president. When resign he writes to the president.

Qualification: The persons who is appointed for the the post of attorney general should be eligible to become a judge of supreme court. The qualification for the supreme court judge is 1. He should be indian citizens. 2. He should have remained as a judge of the high court for five years. 3. He should have been an advocate for ten years.
The attorney general represents the union government in the court.
